key_work.title: My Brilliant Career paperback
key_work.brief_description: My Brilliant Career, adapted from Stella Miles Franklin’s 1901 novel of the same name, was Gillian Armstrong’s first feature film and a global success, gaining Academy Award and Palme d’Or nominations.

constellations_primary.name: Pen names, poems and puppets
constellations_primary.description: Discover how big-screen adaptations of novels connect to web-based poetry and Jim Henson's Fraggle Rock.

start.title: Oscar and Lucinda
start.creator_credit: Robin Dalton, Timothy White, Luciana Arrighi and Janet Patterson
start.headline_credit: Australia, United Kingdom and United States of America, 1997
start.brief_description: Oscar and Lucinda is a 1997 British-Australian romantic drama film directed by Gillian Armstrong and starring Cate Blanchett, Ralph Fiennes, Ciarán Hinds and Tom Wilkinson.

constellations_other.name: Pen names, poems and puppets
constellations_other.description: Discover how big-screen adaptations of novels connect to web-based poetry and Jim Henson's Fraggle Rock.

end.title: Dead End Drive-In
end.creator_credit: Andrew Williams and Roger Cowland
end.brief_description: In the near future, drive-in theatres are turned into concentration camps for the undesirable and unemployed. The prisoners don’t really care to escape because they are fed and they have a place to live which is, in most cases, probably better than the outside. Crabs and his girlfriend Carmen are put into the camp and all Crabs wants to do is escape.

constellations_other.name: Pen names, poems and puppets
constellations_other.description: Discover how big-screen adaptations of novels connect to web-based poetry and Jim Henson's Fraggle Rock.

links.description: In 1986 Brian Trenchard-Smith made Dead End Drive-In which was adapted from Peter Carey’s short story ‘Crabs’.

start.title: Dead End Drive-In
start.brief_description: In the near future, drive-in theatres are turned into concentration camps for the undesirable and unemployed. The prisoners don’t really care to escape because they are fed and they have a place to live which is, in most cases, probably better than the outside. Crabs and his girlfriend Carmen are put into the camp and all Crabs wants to do is escape.

end.title: Drive-In Horror
end.credit_line:
Edie Kurzer, Australia 2020

Drive-in cinema blueprint

Courtesy of David Kilderry, Lunar Drive-In Dandenong
end.brief_description: Sweeping Australia in the 1950s and based on the American model, the drive-in cinema became one of the country’s most popular theatrical experiences. Capitalising on the communal experience and outdoor environment, genre films – and horror in particular – thrived in this format. Australia’s first drive-in cinema, the Skyline, opened in Burwood, Melbourne in 1954, followed by the Lunar Drive-In in Dandenong in 1956, which is still operating. At the peak of their popularity, there were over 330 drive-ins across the country, before a downturn in the 1980s. Their place in popular culture was cemented when Ozploitation director Brian Trenchard-Smith used one as his futuristic prison in dystopian horror film Dead End Drive-In in 1986.

constellations_other.name: Pen names, poems and puppets
constellations_other.description: Discover how big-screen adaptations of novels connect to web-based poetry and Jim Henson's Fraggle Rock.

links.description: Drive-in cinemas were one of the most popular forms of entertainment from the 1950s. At their peak, there were over 330 across the country and their place in pop culture was cemented by Dead End Drive-In

links.description: Gillian Armstrong’s My Brilliant Career and Oscar and Lucinda both have their origins on the page —My Brilliant Career was based on a Miles Franklin (Stella Maria Sarah Miles Franklin) novel and Oscar and Lucinda was based on Peter Carey’s Miles Franklin award-winning novel.

The prisoners don’t really care to escape because they are fed and they have a place to live which is, in most cases, probably better than the outside. Crabs and his girlfriend Carmen are put into the camp and all Crabs wants to do is escape.

end.title: Aleph Null
end.brief_description: Aleph Null is color music. No audio. It’s an online, generative, interactive, open source visual work written in JavaScript using the HTML5 canvas tag.

constellations_other.name: Pen names, poems and puppets
constellations_other.description: Discover how big-screen adaptations of novels connect to web-based poetry and Jim Henson's Fraggle Rock.

links.description: ‘Crabs’ was first published in 1972 in the literary journal Overland, which continues to publish a quarterly print journal and has also published special online editions of digital art and literature. Jim Andrews’s ‘Aleph Null’ was published in the 2013 electronic Overland issue.

start.title: Aleph Null
start.brief_description: Aleph Null is color music. No audio. It’s an online, generative, interactive, open source visual work written in JavaScript using the HTML5 canvas tag.

constellations_other.name: Pen names, poems and puppets
constellations_other.description: Discover how big-screen adaptations of novels connect to web-based poetry and Jim Henson's Fraggle Rock.

end.title: First Screening: Computer Poems
end.brief_description: A suite of a dozen kinetic poems programmed in Apple BASIC. Later, as the first versions became inaccessible, the works were recreated in HyperCard in the early 1990s (after bpNichol’s death), and then in 2007 recreated in javascript for the web, and simultaneously the original BASIC and Hypercard files were republished for download.

constellations_other.name: Pen names, poems and puppets
constellations_other.description: Discover how big-screen adaptations of novels connect to web-based poetry and Jim Henson's Fraggle Rock.

links.description: While an accomplished poet and artist Jim Andrews also worked to update and make accessible renowned Canadian experimental poet bpNichol’s (Barrie Phillip Nichol) ‘First Screening: Computer Poems’.

start.title: First Screening: Computer Poems
start.brief_description: A suite of a dozen kinetic poems programmed in Apple BASIC. Later, as the first versions became inaccessible, the works were recreated in HyperCard in the early 1990s (after bpNichol’s death), and then in 2007 recreated in javascript for the web, and simultaneously the original BASIC and Hypercard files were republished for download.

constellations_other.name: Pen names, poems and puppets
constellations_other.description: Discover how big-screen adaptations of novels connect to web-based poetry and Jim Henson's Fraggle Rock.

end.title: Fraggle Rock
end.creator_credit: Jerry Juhl, Jim Henson, CBC and Henson Associates, Inc.
end.brief_description: The Fraggles are a fun-loving community of creatures who live in a subterranean fantasy land where they love to play, sing and dance their cares away, sharing their world with the tiny Doozers and the giant Gorgs. The series teaches empathy and tolerance and encourages children to understand people different from themselves.

constellations_other.name: Pen names, poems and puppets
constellations_other.description: Discover how big-screen adaptations of novels connect to web-based poetry and Jim Henson's Fraggle Rock.

links.description: Though better known as an experimental poet, bpNichol also worked as a writer on children’s television. Initially writing for Jim Henson’s Fraggle Rock he would go on to write for shows such as Care Bears and Babar.

_source.name: Sci-fi, surrealism and strangeness
_source.description: Step through Portal 2 to explore the links between its sci-fi comedy and the world of film and TV.

key_work.title: Portal 2
key_work.brief_description: Portal 2 is an award-winning first-person puzzle adventure game, set in a crumbling science facility known as Aperture Labs.

constellations_primary.name: Sci-fi, surrealism and strangeness
constellations_primary.description: Step through Portal 2 to explore the links between its sci-fi comedy and the world of film and TV.

start.title: Portal 2
start.brief_description: Portal 2 is an award-winning first-person puzzle adventure game, set in a crumbling science facility known as Aperture Labs.

constellations_primary.name: Sci-fi, surrealism and strangeness
constellations_primary.description: Step through Portal 2 to explore the links between its sci-fi comedy and the world of film and TV.

end.title: Garth Marenghi's Darkplace
end.creator_credit: Charlie Hanson
end.brief_description: When the Hellmouth opens beneath Darkplace Hospital in downtown Romford, kiddy doctor, Vietnam veteran and ex-warlock Dr. Rick Dagless M.D. (Garth Marenghi) is the only man who can close it. Joined by best buddy Dr. Lucien Sanchez (Todd Rivers), fiery hospital boss Thornton Reed (Dean Learner), and woman Liz Asher (Madeleine Wool), Dagless must fight the forces of Darkness while dealing with the burden of day-to-day admin. From the chilling pen of best-selling horror writer Garth Marenghi comes this lost masterpiece of televisual terror. Dare you enter Garth’s Darkplace?

constellations_other.name: Sci-fi, surrealism and strangeness
constellations_other.description: Step through Portal 2 to explore the links between its sci-fi comedy and the world of film and TV.

links.description: Portal 2 features the voice talents of Stephen Merchant and is a humorous take on science fiction tropes. Merchant also plays a key role in horror / supernatural spoof Garth Marenghi’s Darkplace.

start.title: Portal 2
start.brief_description: Portal 2 is an award-winning first-person puzzle adventure game, set in a crumbling science facility known as Aperture Labs.

constellations_primary.name: Sci-fi, surrealism and strangeness
constellations_primary.description: Step through Portal 2 to explore the links between its sci-fi comedy and the world of film and TV.

end.title: Super 8
end.creator_credit: Steven Spielberg, J.J. Abrams and Bryan Burk
end.brief_description: In 1979 Ohio, several youngsters are making a zombie movie with a Super-8 camera. In the midst of filming, the friends witness a horrifying train derailment and are lucky to escape with their lives.

constellations_other.name: Splicing history and silencing the lambs
constellations_other.description: With plastic strips coated with light-sensitive emulsions, film strips captured light and created moving pictures. In this Constellation we trace celluloid and splicing as plot device to serial killers, secrets agents and Super 8.

constellations_other.name: Sci-fi, surrealism and strangeness
constellations_other.description: Step through Portal 2 to explore the links between its sci-fi comedy and the world of film and TV.

constellations_other.name: Making home movies
constellations_other.description: Home movies have inspired the form and plots of narrative cinema.

links.description: To promote the move of nostalgic supernatural adventure Super 8, an interactive teaser level of the train sequence from the film was included in Portal 2.

end.headline_credit: United Kingdom and United States of America, 2017
end.brief_description: Croydon, 1977. A trio of punk teenagers goes to a party to meet girls, but they find that girls there are very different from what they expected.

constellations_other.name: Sci-fi, surrealism and strangeness
constellations_other.description: Step through Portal 2 to explore the links between its sci-fi comedy and the world of film and TV.

links.description: After playing one of the intrepid kids who discover the alien in Super 8, actor Elle Fanning evolves into playing extraterrestrial life in punk sci-fi comedy How to Talk to Girls at Parties.

links.description: The Mighty Boosh is another surreal and comedic British supernatural series, featuring much of the same cast as Darkplace, including Noel Fielding, Julien Barret and Matt Berry.

_source.name: Storytime animated
_source.description: Abra Cadabra was the world's first stereoscopic 3D film, but animators and filmmakers had experimented with the technology far earlier and continue to use other older techniques like stop-motion animation.

key_work.title: Abra Cadabra
key_work.credit_line: ACMI Collection. Donated by the Stitt Family
key_work.brief_description: Australian cartoonist Alexander Stitt is best known for creating the ‘Life. Be in It’ advertisements, along with characters from the ‘Slip-Slop-Slap’ ads, but in 1983 he made the first 3D animated film, Abra Cadabra.

constellations_primary.name: Storytime animated
constellations_primary.description: Abra Cadabra was the world's first stereoscopic 3D film, but animators and filmmakers had experimented with the technology far earlier and continue to use other older techniques like stop-motion animation.

start.title: Coraline
start.creator_credit: Claire Jennings, Bill Mechanic, Mary Sandell, Henry Selick, Harry Linden, Focus Features, Laika Entertainment, Neil Gaiman, Kent Burton, Eric Wachtman, Pandemonium and Margaret Meyer
start.brief_description: An adventurous girl walks through a secret door in her new home and discovers a strangely idealised version of her frustrating home, but it has sinister secrets.

constellations_other.name: Storytime animated
constellations_other.description: Abra Cadabra was the world's first stereoscopic 3D film, but animators and filmmakers had experimented with the technology far earlier and continue to use other older techniques like stop-motion animation.

end.title: Mary and Max
end.creator_credit: Melanie Coombs and icon
end.brief_description: A tale of friendship between two unlikely pen pals: Mary, a lonely, eight-year-old girl living in the suburbs of Melbourne, and Max, a forty-four-year old, severely obese man living in New York, for which Adam Elliot won an Academy Award.

constellations_other.name: Culture and identity on the Australian screen
constellations_other.description: Australian screen culture is distinctive, unexpected, playful and serious when it matters. Indigenous productions make a huge contribution to the unique identity of the Australian moving image.

constellations_other.name: Storytime animated
constellations_other.description: Abra Cadabra was the world's first stereoscopic 3D film, but animators and filmmakers had experimented with the technology far earlier and continue to use other older techniques like stop-motion animation.

links.description: Adam Elliot’s Mary and Max similarly used stop-motion animation, which he described as a “clayography” (clay biography) and drew upon his experience writing to a penfriend in New York for over 25 years to sensitively depict mental health issues.

end.title: Pingu
end.creator_credit: Trickfilm, HiT Entertainment and Silvio Mazzola
end.brief_description: Pingu is a BAFTA award-winning British-Swiss stop-motion claymated television series created by Otmar Gutmann.

constellations_other.name: Storytime animated
constellations_other.description: Abra Cadabra was the world's first stereoscopic 3D film, but animators and filmmakers had experimented with the technology far earlier and continue to use other older techniques like stop-motion animation.

links.description: Also using stop-motion techniques, TV show Pingu centered around the lovable but naughty penguin Pingu and his family. The charming series used the fictionalised Penguinese, which was designed to sound like a real language but was basically gibberish.

start.title: Pingu
start.creator_credit: Trickfilm, HiT Entertainment and Silvio Mazzola

constellations_other.name: Storytime animated
constellations_other.description: Abra Cadabra was the world's first stereoscopic 3D film, but animators and filmmakers had experimented with the technology far earlier and continue to use other older techniques like stop-motion animation.

end.title: The Cameraman's Revenge
end.creator_credit: Aleksandr Khanzhonkov, Khanzhonkov and Wladyslaw Starewicz
end.brief_description: A jilted husband takes his revenge by filming his wife and her lover and showing the result at the local cinema. This was one of Starewicz’ first animated films, and stars a cast of animated beetles.

constellations_other.name: Storytime animated
constellations_other.description: Abra Cadabra was the world's first stereoscopic 3D film, but animators and filmmakers had experimented with the technology far earlier and continue to use other older techniques like stop-motion animation.

links.description: Stop motion techniques had previously been used in cinema but Ladislas Starewicz took them to new heights in 1912 with his story of insect adultery. With incredibly detailed gestures and props, Starewicz was able to bring his dead bug collection to life.

start.title: Abra Cadabra
start.credit_line: ACMI Collection. Donated by the Stitt Family
start.brief_description: Australian cartoonist Alexander Stitt is best known for creating the ‘Life. Be in It’ advertisements, along with characters from the ‘Slip-Slop-Slap’ ads, but in 1983 he made the first 3D animated film, Abra Cadabra.

constellations_primary.name: Storytime animated
constellations_primary.description: Abra Cadabra was the world's first stereoscopic 3D film, but animators and filmmakers had experimented with the technology far earlier and continue to use other older techniques like stop-motion animation.

end.title: Boo Moon
end.creator_credit: Isadore Klein, Seymour Kneitel, Izzy Sparber and Famous Studios
end.brief_description: Casper the Friendly Ghost comes to the aid of King Luna and his people after being attacked by invading Tree Men. On the 3D Bluray 3-D Rarities Volume 1, this appears as an extra in 3D.

constellations_other.name: Storytime animated
constellations_other.description: Abra Cadabra was the world's first stereoscopic 3D film, but animators and filmmakers had experimented with the technology far earlier and continue to use other older techniques like stop-motion animation.

links.description: Abra Cadabra was the world’s first animated feature in stereoscopic 3D, but filmmakers had been creating animated 3D shorts since the 1950s, like Famous Studios’ Boo Moon, which featured Casper the Friendly Ghost appearing to fly into the audience.

start.title: Coraline
start.creator_credit: Claire Jennings, Bill Mechanic, Mary Sandell, Henry Selick, Harry Linden, Focus Features, Laika Entertainment, Neil Gaiman, Kent Burton, Eric Wachtman, Pandemonium and Margaret Meyer
start.brief_description: An adventurous girl walks through a secret door in her new home and discovers a strangely idealised version of her frustrating home, but it has sinister secrets.

constellations_other.name: Storytime animated
constellations_other.description: Abra Cadabra was the world's first stereoscopic 3D film, but animators and filmmakers had experimented with the technology far earlier and continue to use other older techniques like stop-motion animation.

end.title: Coraline
end.brief_description: Coraline lets players take on the role of the adventurous heroine Coraline and interact with the wondrous characters from the movie while navigating the scheming Other Mother’s web of deceit in a fantastical adventure through two distinct and interactive worlds.

constellations_other.name: Storytime animated
constellations_other.description: Abra Cadabra was the world's first stereoscopic 3D film, but animators and filmmakers had experimented with the technology far earlier and continue to use other older techniques like stop-motion animation.

links.description: Soon after the theatrical release, D3 Publisher released an adventure game based on the film. Coraline the videogame saw three main actors reprise their roles but the videogame received negative reviews with many suggesting it was both too hard and scary for children.

end.title: My Neighbor Totoro
end.creator_credit: Ned Lott, Toshio Suzuki, Tooru Hara and Tokuma Shoten
end.brief_description: Two sisters move to the country with their father in order to be closer to their hospitalised mother and discover the surrounding trees are inhabited by Totoros, magical spirits of the forest in this beloved Studio Ghibli classic.

constellations_other.name: Optical toys, Totoro and terrors
constellations_other.description: Victorian-era optical toys have inspired the biggest animation studios and the scariest horror films.

constellations_other.name: Storytime animated
constellations_other.description: Abra Cadabra was the world's first stereoscopic 3D film, but animators and filmmakers had experimented with the technology far earlier and continue to use other older techniques like stop-motion animation.

links.description: In 2005, Dakota Fanning voiced Satsuki in the English version of Hayao Miyazaki beloved classic from 1988, My Neighbor Tortoro. Her sister Elle Fanning was also cast as Mei Kusakabe.

start.title: Boo Moon
start.creator_credit: Isadore Klein, Seymour Kneitel, Izzy Sparber and Famous Studios
start.brief_description: Casper the Friendly Ghost comes to the aid of King Luna and his people after being attacked by invading Tree Men. On the 3D Bluray 3-D Rarities Volume 1, this appears as an extra in 3D.

constellations_other.name: Storytime animated
constellations_other.description: Abra Cadabra was the world's first stereoscopic 3D film, but animators and filmmakers had experimented with the technology far earlier and continue to use other older techniques like stop-motion animation.

end.title: Coraline
end.creator_credit: Claire Jennings, Bill Mechanic, Mary Sandell, Henry Selick, Harry Linden, Focus Features, Laika Entertainment, Neil Gaiman, Kent Burton, Eric Wachtman, Pandemonium and Margaret Meyer
end.brief_description: An adventurous girl walks through a secret door in her new home and discovers a strangely idealised version of her frustrating home, but it has sinister secrets.

constellations_other.name: Storytime animated
constellations_other.description: Abra Cadabra was the world's first stereoscopic 3D film, but animators and filmmakers had experimented with the technology far earlier and continue to use other older techniques like stop-motion animation.

links.description: The hauntingly beautiful Coraline also employed 3D to construct a greater sense of wonder and depth into the mysterious ‘other world’. Caroline’s real world appears slightly flat and cramped while the other world is glossier and endless heightened by incorporating 3D technology.

_source.name: Future visions
_source.description: Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections.

key_work.title: Entities
key_work.creator_credit: OOM Creative, MORE Studio, Greg More (OOM Creative), Pete Brundle (MORE Studio) and James Sandri (MORE Studio)
key_work.brief_description: Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections.

constellations_primary.name: Future visions
constellations_primary.description: Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections.

start.title: Blade Runner
start.creator_credit: Michael Deeley, Ridley Scott, Douglas Trumbull, Richard Yuricich and Shaw Brothers
start.headline_credit: Hong Kong, United Kingdom and United States of America, 1982
start.brief_description: In the smog-choked dystopian Los Angeles of 2019, blade runner Rick Deckard is called out of retirement to terminate a quartet of replicants who have escaped to Earth seeking their creator for a way to extend their short life spans.

constellations_primary.name: Explosive footage
constellations_primary.description: How the fireballs in the opening scene of Blade Runner connect to Fatboy Slim and Detective Pikachu.

constellations_other.name: Future visions
constellations_other.description: Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections.

constellations_other.name: Expansive light in science fiction and fantasy
constellations_other.description: Visual artists have identified the importance of light in revealing the expansiveness of our universe. Explore how artists’ perception of light has been adapted and referenced in science fiction and fantasy on screen.

constellations_other.name: Little, big worlds
constellations_other.description: Wes Anderson's stop-motion animation film draws on tried-and-true techniques that, despite the rise of computer-generated imagery, still inspire filmmakers and game-makers.

constellations_other.name: Alternate histories and futures
constellations_other.description: Sue Ford's Egami reimagines contemporary life through a feminist and colonial lens.

constellations_other.name: Evil AI, dystopias and production design
constellations_other.description: In No Code’s sci-fi thriller players take command of a multi-national space station’s artificial intelligence system to help the sole survivor solve the mystery of a missing crew and why the station is wildly off course.

constellations_other.name: The Kubrick connection
constellations_other.description: The visual effects for Blade Runner drew on a number of techniques from other iconic films, including two of Stanley Kubrick's masterpieces.

constellations_other.name: Sci-fi miniatures
constellations_other.description: As filmmaking technologies have changed and evolved over the decades, much like audiences, miniatures have endured as one of the most effective film special effects.

constellations_other.name: Arcades and AI
constellations_other.description: Using the godfather of computing, Alan Turing, as a starting point, this Constellation traces the evolution of AI representation on-screen and the way female androids, robots and holograms have been hyper sexualised.

end.title: Shadowrun
end.creator_credit: Data East USA and Beam Software
end.brief_description: In the early 1990s, Nintendo didn’t allow sex, drugs and alcohol to appear on its consoles. Games also couldn’t show blood or graphic violence. This presented a challenge for Australian developers Beam Software, who were turning the gritty pen-and-paper roleplaying game Shadowrun into a future classic.

constellations_other.name: Future visions
constellations_other.description: Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections.

links.description: The tech, neo-noir dystopia of Blade Runner shares a similar mood and atmosphere as the world of Shadowrun.

start.title: Entities
start.creator_credit: OOM Creative, MORE Studio, Greg More (OOM Creative), Pete Brundle (MORE Studio) and James Sandri (MORE Studio)
start.brief_description: Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections.

constellations_primary.name: Future visions
constellations_primary.description: Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections.

end.title: Data Tapestry
end.creator_credit: Greg Moore
end.brief_description: Data Tapestry is a commissioned data-art work for the National Gallery of Victoria (NGV) Melbourne Now exhibition. The work creates a departure point for thinking about our contemporary city through ecological, demographic, and systems data sourced from the greater Melbourne region.

constellations_other.name: Future visions
constellations_other.description: Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections.

links.description: Data Tapestry is a commissioned data artwork for the National Gallery of Victoria’s (NGV) Melbourne Now exhibition. The work creates a departure point for thinking about our contemporary city through ecological, demographic, and systems data sourced from the greater Melbourne region.

The work creates a departure point for thinking about our contemporary city through ecological, demographic, and systems data sourced from the greater Melbourne region.

links.description: While Data Tapesty presents different themes of Melbourne city, like ftraffic accidents and trees Aaron Koblin’s data-visualisation Flight Patterns takes a national scope, presenting every airline flight over North America in a 24-hour period.

constellations_other.name: Future visions
constellations_other.description: Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections.

end.title: Sunspring
end.creator_credit: Oscar Sharp and Benjamin
end.brief_description: Sunspring is a short film about three people living in a weird future, possibly on a space station, probably in a love triangle.

constellations_other.name: Future visions
constellations_other.description: Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections.

links.description: While data-visualisations rely on algorithms and web-technologies to create their mesmerising sights, algorithms have also been used by filmmakers to create robot scripts like Sunspring, which Oscar Sharp and Ross Goodwin made by inputting sci-fi scripts into a machine learning algorithm.

start.title: Sunspring
start.brief_description: Sunspring is a short film about three people living in a weird future, possibly on a space station, probably in a love triangle.

constellations_other.name: Future visions
constellations_other.description: Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections.

end.title: Blade Runner
end.creator_credit: Michael Deeley, Ridley Scott, Douglas Trumbull, Richard Yuricich and Shaw Brothers
end.headline_credit: Hong Kong, United Kingdom and United States of America, 1982
end.brief_description: In the smog-choked dystopian Los Angeles of 2019, blade runner Rick Deckard is called out of retirement to terminate a quartet of replicants who have escaped to Earth seeking their creator for a way to extend their short life spans.

constellations_primary.name: Explosive footage
constellations_primary.description: How the fireballs in the opening scene of Blade Runner connect to Fatboy Slim and Detective Pikachu.

constellations_other.name: Future visions
constellations_other.description: Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections.

constellations_other.name: Expansive light in science fiction and fantasy
constellations_other.description: Visual artists have identified the importance of light in revealing the expansiveness of our universe. Explore how artists’ perception of light has been adapted and referenced in science fiction and fantasy on screen.

constellations_other.name: Little, big worlds
constellations_other.description: Wes Anderson's stop-motion animation film draws on tried-and-true techniques that, despite the rise of computer-generated imagery, still inspire filmmakers and game-makers.

constellations_other.name: Alternate histories and futures
constellations_other.description: Sue Ford's Egami reimagines contemporary life through a feminist and colonial lens.

constellations_other.name: Evil AI, dystopias and production design
constellations_other.description: In No Code’s sci-fi thriller players take command of a multi-national space station’s artificial intelligence system to help the sole survivor solve the mystery of a missing crew and why the station is wildly off course.

constellations_other.name: The Kubrick connection
constellations_other.description: The visual effects for Blade Runner drew on a number of techniques from other iconic films, including two of Stanley Kubrick's masterpieces.

constellations_other.name: Sci-fi miniatures
constellations_other.description: As filmmaking technologies have changed and evolved over the decades, much like audiences, miniatures have endured as one of the most effective film special effects.

constellations_other.name: Arcades and AI
constellations_other.description: Using the godfather of computing, Alan Turing, as a starting point, this Constellation traces the evolution of AI representation on-screen and the way female androids, robots and holograms have been hyper sexualised.

links.description: One of the godfather’s of sci-fi tropes is Ridley Scott’s Blade Runner, which helped establish the look and feel of a smog-choked, neon-lit near future. It also features machines that have grown sentient like algorithms might one day….

end.title: 2001: A Space Odyssey
end.creator_credit: Stanley Kubrick and Victor Lyndon
end.headline_credit: United Kingdom and United States of America, 1968
end.brief_description: Humanity finds a mysterious object buried beneath the lunar surface and sets off to find its origins with the help of HAL 9000, the world’s most advanced super computer, in Stanley Kubrick’s masterpiece, which pushed cinematic narratives and special effects.

constellations_other.name: Space, sci-fi and cinema fakes
constellations_other.description: Magic lantern slides were used to entertain and educate audiences in home, theatres and universities. While performers told jokes and fairytales, travelling showmen unveiled exotic locations and scientists revealed the latest discoveries.

constellations_other.name: Sounds unreal
constellations_other.description: A history of syncing sound effects, a craft known as Foley in the USA and bootstepping in the UK.

constellations_other.name: Future visions
constellations_other.description: Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections.

constellations_other.name: Kaleidoscopic colour: Chromotrope
constellations_other.description: A focus on distinctive and innovative examples of pattern, colour and movement.

constellations_other.name: Auteurs, influence and inspiration
constellations_other.description: A tradition of influence and inspiration beginning with Eisenstein.

constellations_other.name: The Kubrick connection
constellations_other.description: The visual effects for Blade Runner drew on a number of techniques from other iconic films, including two of Stanley Kubrick's masterpieces.

constellations_other.name: Evil AI, dystopias and production design
constellations_other.description: In No Code’s sci-fi thriller players take command of a multi-national space station’s artificial intelligence system to help the sole survivor solve the mystery of a missing crew and why the station is wildly off course.

constellations_other.name: Sublime light and special effects
constellations_other.description: Explore 19th-century artist John Martin’s surprising influence on science fiction and fantasy films of the 20th century, from Jason and the Argonauts to the Lord of the Rings and the Evil Dead franchises.

links.description: Legendary special effects master and director Douglas Trumbull oversaw the VFX in Blade Runner, but he also worked on Stanley Kubrick’s 2001, where he designed the Star Gate sequence, which set the standard for how we visualise space travel.

links.description: Because of its cultural and cinematic impact, 2001 (and Blade Runner for that matter) are two of the most connected works in the entire Constellation, which is represented by Entities.

_source.name: Culture and identity on the Australian screen
_source.description: Australian screen culture is distinctive, unexpected, playful and serious when it matters. Indigenous productions make a huge contribution to the unique identity of the Australian moving image.

key_work.title: Bush Mechanics car replica
key_work.creator_credit: Francis Jupurrula Kelly and Thomas Rice
key_work.credit_line: Produced by Rebel Films and commissioned by ACMI
key_work.material_description: Steel, aluminium, plastic, Mulga branch, fencing wire, automotive paint, acrylic paint

constellations_primary.name: Culture and identity on the Australian screen
constellations_primary.description: Australian screen culture is distinctive, unexpected, playful and serious when it matters. Indigenous productions make a huge contribution to the unique identity of the Australian moving image.

start.title: Bush Mechanics
start.brief_description: David Batty and Francis Jupurrurla Kelly’s Bush Mechanics (2001) became a cult classic and spawned short films, museum exhibitions and even a videogame. This Warlpiri-language miniseries owes its popularity to its distinctive cultural world of Warlpiri humour, music and experience.

constellations_other.name: Alternate histories and futures
constellations_other.description: Sue Ford's Egami reimagines contemporary life through a feminist and colonial lens.

constellations_other.name: Laughing in the face of adversity
constellations_other.description: Comedy has been used by First Nations storytellers as a tool for social change. On our screens, humour invites audiences to engage with stories and prompts them to grapple with ideas that they otherwise might shy away from.

constellations_other.name: Culture and identity on the Australian screen
constellations_other.description: Australian screen culture is distinctive, unexpected, playful and serious when it matters. Indigenous productions make a huge contribution to the unique identity of the Australian moving image.

end.title: Malcolm
end.creator_credit: David Parker
end.brief_description: Malcolm is a 1986 Australian cult film, written by David Parker and directed by Nadia Tass. The film stars Colin Friels as the titular tram enthusiast who becomes involved with petty crime. The film won the 1986 Australian Film Institute Award for Best Film.

constellations_other.name: Culture and identity on the Australian screen
constellations_other.description: Australian screen culture is distinctive, unexpected, playful and serious when it matters. Indigenous productions make a huge contribution to the unique identity of the Australian moving image.

constellations_other.name: Nadia Tass
constellations_other.description: Comedic and cult classics take centre stage in Nadia Tass' career.

links.description: Young men from Yuendumu travel through country, facing challenges with zany good humour and keeping their cars going with inventive bush repair techniques. Malcolm also features whacky ingenuity and re-purposed vehicles including a car that divides in half.

start.title: Malcolm
start.brief_description: Malcolm is a 1986 Australian cult film, written by David Parker and directed by Nadia Tass. The film stars Colin Friels as the titular tram enthusiast who becomes involved with petty crime. The film won the 1986 Australian Film Institute Award for Best Film.

constellations_other.name: Culture and identity on the Australian screen
constellations_other.description: Australian screen culture is distinctive, unexpected, playful and serious when it matters. Indigenous productions make a huge contribution to the unique identity of the Australian moving image.

constellations_other.name: Nadia Tass
constellations_other.description: Comedic and cult classics take centre stage in Nadia Tass' career.

end.title: Mary and Max
end.creator_credit: Melanie Coombs and icon
end.brief_description: A tale of friendship between two unlikely pen pals: Mary, a lonely, eight-year-old girl living in the suburbs of Melbourne, and Max, a forty-four-year old, severely obese man living in New York, for which Adam Elliot won an Academy Award.

constellations_other.name: Culture and identity on the Australian screen
constellations_other.description: Australian screen culture is distinctive, unexpected, playful and serious when it matters. Indigenous productions make a huge contribution to the unique identity of the Australian moving image.

constellations_other.name: Storytime animated
constellations_other.description: Abra Cadabra was the world's first stereoscopic 3D film, but animators and filmmakers had experimented with the technology far earlier and continue to use other older techniques like stop-motion animation.

links.description: Malcolm’s childlike perspective is highlighted through the playful discordance of compositions by the Penguin Cafe Orchestra, including Perpetuum Mobile. In Mary and Max, this repetitious piece communicates the main characters’ innocent dreams for a better life.

start.title: Mary and Max
start.brief_description: A tale of friendship between two unlikely pen pals: Mary, a lonely, eight-year-old girl living in the suburbs of Melbourne, and Max, a forty-four-year old, severely obese man living in New York, for which Adam Elliot won an Academy Award.

constellations_other.name: Culture and identity on the Australian screen
constellations_other.description: Australian screen culture is distinctive, unexpected, playful and serious when it matters. Indigenous productions make a huge contribution to the unique identity of the Australian moving image.

constellations_other.name: Storytime animated
constellations_other.description: Abra Cadabra was the world's first stereoscopic 3D film, but animators and filmmakers had experimented with the technology far earlier and continue to use other older techniques like stop-motion animation.

end.title: Bush Mechanics animation (2015)
end.brief_description: In the central Australian desert, four Warlpiri men travel to visit a powerful elder at a remote outstation. On the road they must overcome mechanical mishaps and the trickery of a mischievous spirit. It will take all of their bush ingenuity to keep their car running and themselves alive.

constellations_other.name: Culture and identity on the Australian screen
constellations_other.description: Australian screen culture is distinctive, unexpected, playful and serious when it matters. Indigenous productions make a huge contribution to the unique identity of the Australian moving image.

links.description: The hand-made claymation technique used in Mary and Max foregrounds the process of creation in a very human way making it the perfect medium for animating the improvised and do-it-yourself creativity of the Bush Mechanics.

start.title: Bush Mechanics animation (2015)
start.brief_description: In the central Australian desert, four Warlpiri men travel to visit a powerful elder at a remote outstation. On the road they must overcome mechanical mishaps and the trickery of a mischievous spirit. It will take all of their bush ingenuity to keep their car running and themselves alive.

constellations_other.name: Culture and identity on the Australian screen
constellations_other.description: Australian screen culture is distinctive, unexpected, playful and serious when it matters. Indigenous productions make a huge contribution to the unique identity of the Australian moving image.

end.title: Aboriginal Rules (2006)
end.brief_description: Independently funded 55 minute documentary produced in 2006 by Warlpiri Media Association. Directed by Liam Campbell and co-directed by Francis Jupurrurla Kelly and Neil Jupurrurla White, Aboriginal Rules follows the Yuendumu Magpies AFL team for a year. Over that time we see the highs and lows of their aspiration to win the Central Australia Football League Grand Final. We also get an insight into the challenges of young Aboriginal men growing up on settlements.

constellations_other.name: Culture and identity on the Australian screen
constellations_other.description: Australian screen culture is distinctive, unexpected, playful and serious when it matters. Indigenous productions make a huge contribution to the unique identity of the Australian moving image.

links.description: The Bush Mechanics series and more recent claymation are PAW media productions, a company specialising in producing media in language. PAW media’s documentary, Aboriginal Rules, focuses on the Yuendumu footy team that featured in the Bush Mechanics episode ‘The Chase’.

start.title: Aboriginal Rules (2006)
start.brief_description: Independently funded 55 minute documentary produced in 2006 by Warlpiri Media Association. Directed by Liam Campbell and co-directed by Francis Jupurrurla Kelly and Neil Jupurrurla White, Aboriginal Rules follows the Yuendumu Magpies AFL team for a year. Over that time we see the highs and lows of their aspiration to win the Central Australia Football League Grand Final. We also get an insight into the challenges of young Aboriginal men growing up on settlements.

constellations_other.name: Culture and identity on the Australian screen
constellations_other.description: Australian screen culture is distinctive, unexpected, playful and serious when it matters. Indigenous productions make a huge contribution to the unique identity of the Australian moving image.

end.title: The Marngrook Footy Show
end.brief_description:
The Marngrook Footy Show was a sport panel show broadcast in Australia. Debuting in 2007, the show aired on NITV, and was previously simulcast on Channel 31 Melbourne.

Between 2011 and 2012, the program was broadcast on ABC2, and was shown live in 2012, but had its time-slot moved several times. From 2013 the show is produced by Toombak Indigenous Productions and broadcast on NITV/SBS.[1] The show is produced at the Burwood campus of Deakin University in its professional-standard television studio.

The show was axed in October 2019 after 12 years.

constellations_other.name: Culture and identity on the Australian screen
constellations_other.description: Australian screen culture is distinctive, unexpected, playful and serious when it matters. Indigenous productions make a huge contribution to the unique identity of the Australian moving image.

links.description: Football is an important part of many Aboriginal communities and relates to marngrook, a traditional Indigenous football game. The Marngrook Footy Show is a sports entertainment panel show that offers an Indigenous perspective on the Australian Football League (AFL).

start.title: The Marngrook Footy Show
start.brief_description:
The Marngrook Footy Show was a sport panel show broadcast in Australia. Debuting in 2007, the show aired on NITV, and was previously simulcast on Channel 31 Melbourne.

Between 2011 and 2012, the program was broadcast on ABC2, and was shown live in 2012, but had its time-slot moved several times. From 2013 the show is produced by Toombak Indigenous Productions and broadcast on NITV/SBS.[1] The show is produced at the Burwood campus of Deakin University in its professional-standard television studio.

The show was axed in October 2019 after 12 years.

constellations_other.name: Culture and identity on the Australian screen
constellations_other.description: Australian screen culture is distinctive, unexpected, playful and serious when it matters. Indigenous productions make a huge contribution to the unique identity of the Australian moving image.

end.title: The Australian Dream
end.creator_credit: Virginia Whitwell, Sarah Thomson, Nick Batzias, John Battsek, Passion Pictures, Good Thing Productions, Daniel Gordon and Stan Grant
end.brief_description: The Australian Dream is a theatrical feature documentary that uses the remarkable and inspirational story of AFL legend Adam Goodes as the prism through which to tell a deeper and more powerful story about race, identity and belonging.

constellations_other.name: Culture and identity on the Australian screen
constellations_other.description: Australian screen culture is distinctive, unexpected, playful and serious when it matters. Indigenous productions make a huge contribution to the unique identity of the Australian moving image.

links.description: The Marngrook Footy Show foregrounds the achievements and contributions of Indigenous AFL players, while the documentary The Australian Dream focuses on the experience of AFL legend Adam Goodes to expose of the racism faced by Indigenous players.

start.title: Bush Mechanics
start.brief_description: David Batty and Francis Jupurrurla Kelly’s Bush Mechanics (2001) became a cult classic and spawned short films, museum exhibitions and even a videogame. This Warlpiri-language miniseries owes its popularity to its distinctive cultural world of Warlpiri humour, music and experience.

end.title: Bush Mechanics car replica
end.creator_credit: Francis Jupurrula Kelly and Thomas Rice
end.credit_line: Produced by Rebel Films and commissioned by ACMI
end.material_description: Steel, aluminium, plastic, Mulga branch, fencing wire, automotive paint, acrylic paint

constellations_primary.name: Culture and identity on the Australian screen
constellations_primary.description: Australian screen culture is distinctive, unexpected, playful and serious when it matters. Indigenous productions make a huge contribution to the unique identity of the Australian moving image.

links.description: Demonstrating the winning combination of Warlpiri humour and car culture, Ngapa Jukuurpa (Water Dreaming) is painted on an old Ford ZF Fairlane in the Bush Mechanics‘ final episode, which has been replicated in The Story of the Moving Image.
